commit_message:
Preserve file extension in config-download

Only add the .yaml file extension to files downloaded from the
role_config if they don't already have an extension. This isn't a
foolproof method for detecting an extension, but it will solve most
cases and allow scripts to be saved with a .sh extension instead of
.yaml.

Depends-On: I1434da248bb9bc06e38381a47f274e1480fd450c
Change-Id: I0b3188ef45dc379f83c36561616b422418845b66
implements: blueprint reduce-deployment-resources

commit_message:
Rework create_or_find_kernel_and_ramdisk to match the current reality

This call has been carrying the functionality of uploading images which
we haven't used for a while. However, it doesn't take into account that
ironic supports non-glance images. This change updates it.

Change-Id: I3827f3828023482279753d3139c579e964ef27cf
Implements: blueprint nova-less-deploy

commit_message:
Document restrictions for moving servers between availability zones

There was nothing clearly documented about move operations with
respect to AZ restrictions, i.e. when a server can move between
zones or not, and how forcing a target host during evacuate or
live migration can break tracking of the instance for it's orginally
intended zone. This adds documentation around that topic.

Change-Id: I7466826780ea8a6b3d3df93f0e85f009a437b743
Closes-Bug: #1823043

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-06 13:55:29.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Use SATA bus for cdrom devices when using Q35 machine type

The Q35 machine type no longer provides an IDE bus and will need to use
a SATA bus to attach legacy devices such as cdroms. More details can be
found in the following related bug:

Don't assume the guest machine type to be of 'pc'
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1780138

To enable this the _get_machine_type method is extracted from the
Libvirt driver into the utility module. This allows the method to be
reused by the blockinfo module so a lookup can be preformed to determine
if the Q35 machine type will be used by the instance while looking up
disk mapping information.

The signature of _get_disk_bus_for_device_type has changed to
accommodate the passing of LibvirtDriver._host. This allows the host
capabilities to be passed to the extracted get_machine_type method. This
unfortunately results in a large amount of unavoidable test file damage
as LibvirtDriver._host also needs to be passed around via
get_info_from_bdm, get_root_info, default_device_names, get_disk_mapping
and get_disk_info.

Related-bug: 1780138
Closes-bug: 1831538
Change-Id: Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
(cherry picked from commit 5a201879717c6534a4d5a87cec9059afc925921f)
"}, {'created': '2019-06-13 07:35:35.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Use SATA bus for cdrom devices when using Q35 machine type

The Q35 machine type no longer provides an IDE bus and will need to use
a SATA bus to attach legacy devices such as cdroms. More details can be
found in the following related bug:

Don't assume the guest machine type to be of 'pc'
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1780138

This change now ensures the blockinfo.get_disk_bus_for_device_type
method will now return "sata" as the bus type when the Q35 machine type
is used for cdrom devices on QEMU or KVM hosts that are not PPC, S390 or
AArch64 based.

To enable this the _get_machine_type method has been extracted from the
Libvirt driver into the Libvirt utils module. This method has also been
simplified through the removal of the caps parameter, replaced with
calls to the get_arch utility method and additional extraction of
architecture specific defaults into the existing
get_default_machine_type utility method.

Related-bug: 1780138
Closes-bug: 1831538
Change-Id: Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
(cherry picked from commit 527c452a6fc05a316eb8121796f761af97522772)
'}, {'created': '2019-06-13 15:56:58.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Use SATA bus for cdrom devices when using Q35 machine type

The Q35 machine type no longer provides an IDE bus and will need to use
a SATA bus to attach legacy devices such as cdroms. More details can be
found in the following related bug:

Don't assume the guest machine type to be of 'pc'
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1780138

This change now ensures the blockinfo.get_disk_bus_for_device_type
method will now return "sata" as the bus type when the Q35 machine type
is used for cdrom devices on QEMU or KVM hosts that are not PPC, S390 or
AArch64 based.

To enable this the _get_machine_type method has been extracted from the
Libvirt driver into the Libvirt utils module. This method has also been
simplified through the removal of the caps parameter, replaced with
calls to the get_arch utility method and additional extraction of
architecture specific defaults into the existing
get_default_machine_type utility method.

Related-bug: 1780138
Closes-bug: 1831538
Change-Id: Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
(cherry picked from commit 527c452a6fc05a316eb8121796f761af97522772)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Use SATA bus for cdrom devices when using Q35 machine type

The Q35 machine type no longer provides an IDE bus and will need to use
a SATA bus to attach legacy devices such as cdroms. More details can be
found in the following related bug:

Don't assume the guest machine type to be of 'pc'
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1780138

This change now ensures the blockinfo.get_disk_bus_for_device_type
method will now return "sata" as the bus type when the Q35 machine type
is used for cdrom devices on QEMU or KVM hosts that are not PPC, S390 or
AArch64 based.

To enable this the _get_machine_type method has been extracted from the
Libvirt driver into the Libvirt utils module. This method has also been
simplified through the removal of the caps parameter, replaced with
calls to the get_arch utility method and additional extraction of
architecture specific defaults into the existing
get_default_machine_type utility method.

Related-bug: 1780138
Closes-bug: 1831538
Change-Id: Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
(cherry picked from commit 527c452a6fc05a316eb8121796f761af97522772)

commit_message:
Rabbitmq: Add pod/container security context

This updates the rabbitmq chart to include the pod
security context on the pod template.

This also adds the container security context to set
readOnlyRootFilesystem to true

Change-Id: I68aa4b49bf6301e1b1004a526151fa0ab4b197b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-14 14:38:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix memory leak in the haproxy provider driver

The haproxy provider driver uses a dict for caching load balancer
resources (including children resources). That alone already increases
memory consumption. A neutron-server restart solves this.

But the real issue is that the driver leaves some data behind when a LB
is deleted without freeing it up (unless neutron-server is restart)
hence the memory leak.

Story: 2003802
Task: 26534

Change-Id: I7c79271998d839c6afbeb6d92f888f6acd67704e
(cherry picked from commit 111d0b285200961fa796532688ae65d4ca801ce8)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix memory leak in the haproxy provider driver

The haproxy provider driver uses a dict for caching load balancer
resources (including children resources). That alone already increases
memory consumption. A neutron-server restart solves this.

But the real issue is that the driver leaves some data behind when a LB
is deleted without freeing it up (unless neutron-server is restart)
hence the memory leak.

Story: 2003802
Task: 26534

Change-Id: I7c79271998d839c6afbeb6d92f888f6acd67704e
(cherry picked from commit 111d0b285200961fa796532688ae65d4ca801ce8)

Pass server_max_value_length to memcached client

Before this commit there was no ability to match client side option
with the server side one.

commit_message:
Fix non-interactive mode for apt

Since sudo was laucnhed after setting DEBIAN_FRONTEND variable,
noninteractive wasn't working correctly during bindep installation.

Also patch includes temporary fix which is generally adressed in [1]
This is implemented to resolve cross-dependency and will be rolled
back once general fix will land.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/665244/

Change-Id: I44c6aa7a0266285ca67edca70cdc4450c64671d9

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-13 14:21:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix double word hacking test

At present, 'pycodestyle' feeds the following string into the 'tokenizer'
library:

    ["'This is the the best comment'"]

(note the added quotes because this isn't valid Python otherwise)

On previous versions of Python, this tokenizer would parse the string like so:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

However, with the fix [1] backported to recent versions of Python, this now
resolves to:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (4, '', (1, 30), (1, 31), '')
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Typically, 'pycodestyle' will run physical line checks on each line as it
parses the token:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2036

For the former case above, the line doesn't include a newline which
means we never parse a 'NEWLINE' token with a logical line (the fifth
element of the token tuple) corresponding to our full line. This means
we don't here but that wasn't an issue previously since there's a
fallthrough case that handled tokens remaining at the end of the parse:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2114-L2116

Unfortunately, because we now have an additional newline character to
parse, one that's on a separate line to our test string no less, we run
logical checks on it:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2105-L2107

This is an issue since the logical check wipes stored tokens meaning
we've nothing to check when we get to the fallthrough case:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2012

This fixes changes things so that a newline is included (and also adds
quotes so it's valid Python, but that's mostly unrelated). This means we
end up with the following instead:

  ["'This is the the best comment'\n"]

On both Python without the bugfix and with it, this parses as:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (4, '\n', (1, 30), (1, 31), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Which triggers things in 'pycodestyle' correctly.

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2044-L2046

This isn't _really_ a fix since there's clearly still a bug in either
'pycodestyle' or Python (I think the latter, since it's adding a newline
to a file that explicitly doesn't have one), but the chances of us
hitting this bug in practice are rather low - you'd need to make a
mistake on the very last line of a file without a newline at the end
which is something Vim, for example, won't even let you do without
setting special flags - and therefore it can be reasonably ignored.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/test_hacking.py

NOTE(stephenfin): Conflicts are because we don't have change
I35c654bd39f343417e0a1124263ff31dcd0b05c9 ("Bump to hacking 1.1.0") or
change I8826c3fb89690805baae6b9b7b48985abb8d62d3 ("Skip
test_check_doubled_words hacking check UT") on this branch.

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue33899

Change-Id: Ia597594e0469c0e83d7ad22b0678390aaebaffe7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1804062
(cherry picked from f545a25cc443c41dcd9bdd028064c28b53f56037)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix double word hacking test

At present, 'pycodestyle' feeds the following string into the 'tokenizer'
library:

    ["'This is the the best comment'"]

(note the added quotes because this isn't valid Python otherwise)

On previous versions of Python, this tokenizer would parse the string like so:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

However, with the fix [1] backported to recent versions of Python, this now
resolves to:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (4, '', (1, 30), (1, 31), '')
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Typically, 'pycodestyle' will run physical line checks on each line as it
parses the token:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2036

For the former case above, the line doesn't include a newline which
means we never parse a 'NEWLINE' token with a logical line (the fifth
element of the token tuple) corresponding to our full line. This means
we don't here but that wasn't an issue previously since there's a
fallthrough case that handled tokens remaining at the end of the parse:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2114-L2116

Unfortunately, because we now have an additional newline character to
parse, one that's on a separate line to our test string no less, we run
logical checks on it:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2105-L2107

This is an issue since the logical check wipes stored tokens meaning
we've nothing to check when we get to the fallthrough case:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2012

This fixes changes things so that a newline is included (and also adds
quotes so it's valid Python, but that's mostly unrelated). This means we
end up with the following instead:

  ["'This is the the best comment'\n"]

On both Python without the bugfix and with it, this parses as:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (4, '\n', (1, 30), (1, 31), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Which triggers things in 'pycodestyle' correctly.

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2044-L2046

This isn't _really_ a fix since there's clearly still a bug in either
'pycodestyle' or Python (I think the latter, since it's adding a newline
to a file that explicitly doesn't have one), but the chances of us
hitting this bug in practice are rather low - you'd need to make a
mistake on the very last line of a file without a newline at the end
which is something Vim, for example, won't even let you do without
setting special flags - and therefore it can be reasonably ignored.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/test_hacking.py

NOTE(stephenfin): Conflicts are because we don't have change
I35c654bd39f343417e0a1124263ff31dcd0b05c9 ("Bump to hacking 1.1.0") or
change I8826c3fb89690805baae6b9b7b48985abb8d62d3 ("Skip
test_check_doubled_words hacking check UT") on this branch.

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue33899

Change-Id: Ia597594e0469c0e83d7ad22b0678390aaebaffe7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1804062
(cherry picked from f545a25cc443c41dcd9bdd028064c28b53f56037)

[{'created': '2019-06-11 07:48:09.000000000', 'message': 'rbac: Catch correct exception for duplicated entry

RBAC network policy is uniquely identified by network ID. That means
when attempting to create such network policy, we should not retry when
such policy already exists in the database.

Before we switched in rbac to use OVO, we translated DB DBDuplicateEntry
on such ocasions into dedicated RBAC exception to avoid DB retry
mechanism (see bug/1551473). After introducing OVO layer for RBAC, the
exception was not changed to the one coming from OVO. This patch
replaces the exception from DB to the exception from OVO.

Another patch will go to neutron-tempest-plugin to limit time API needs
to reply with failure to user, when attempting to create an existing
policy.

Closes-Bug: #1831647

Change-Id: I7c65376f6fd6fc29d510ea532a684917ed95deb1
(cherry picked from commit 26b3e6b1c4622087a2aaa542cb5ac5e477bd47b8)
'}]
commit_message:
rbac: Catch correct exception for duplicated entry

RBAC network policy is uniquely identified by network ID. That means
when attempting to create such network policy, we should not retry when
such policy already exists in the database.

Before we switched in rbac to use OVO, we translated DB DBDuplicateEntry
on such ocasions into dedicated RBAC exception to avoid DB retry
mechanism (see bug/1551473). After introducing OVO layer for RBAC, the
exception was not changed to the one coming from OVO. This patch
replaces the exception from DB to the exception from OVO.

Another patch will go to neutron-tempest-plugin to limit time API needs
to reply with failure to user, when attempting to create an existing
policy.

Closes-Bug: #1831647

Change-Id: I7c65376f6fd6fc29d510ea532a684917ed95deb1
(cherry picked from commit 26b3e6b1c4622087a2aaa542cb5ac5e477bd47b8)

commit_message:
validations: Allow to customize the max retries

The max tries per validation task is currently hardcoded to 40. On
slow nodes it's possible to reach this limit easily.
This patch allows to customize the max retries and set the default
value to 40 as a backward compatibility.

Change-Id: Id23b6a301bea6592bc033ee8aa475933e171e3d8

commit_message:
Add panko_api_cron container

Currently panko expirer isn't running in a separate container,
which results in events piling up in the configured database.
This change deploys panko_api_cron as a container and
periodically deletes events from db

Closes-Bug: #1832274
Change-Id: I4c941048a3561af9458208fe86e1b86156eb7ebc
(cherry picked from commit 66a638a8df8fa5b7c9bb92eb1e9da9d09c1fb447)
(cherry picked from commit 9e876dfe0d743d51283a3462d03991180d3ace51)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-02 13:52:00.000000000', 'message': 'TLS everywhere: switch Octavia to use DNS entries

The entries in the tls-everywhere-endpoints-dns.yaml was wrong for
octavia; pointing to IPs instead of DNS. This made the TLS everywhere
deployment fail, since it assigns certificates for DNS subjectAltNames.

Change-Id: Ic6f0f26c03c443edf1715927a4542245e08567f4
Closes-Bug: #1822035
(cherry picked from commit a0e262e20ce5a111d9c097d9b6c7a7549207aebd)
'}]
commit_message:
TLS everywhere: switch Octavia to use DNS entries

The entries in the tls-everywhere-endpoints-dns.yaml was wrong for
octavia; pointing to IPs instead of DNS. This made the TLS everywhere
deployment fail, since it assigns certificates for DNS subjectAltNames.

Change-Id: Ic6f0f26c03c443edf1715927a4542245e08567f4
Closes-Bug: #1822035
(cherry picked from commit a0e262e20ce5a111d9c097d9b6c7a7549207aebd)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-13 03:56:30.000000000', 'message': 'Pass more accurate error message to DeleteErrorException

Now we can get error messages like "Resource 595f6527-d84c-
4e14-a86f-c7be186a864c failed to delete and is in ERROR status",
and this has two problems:
1. It doesn't indicate which kind of resource, e.g., volume or server
2. For DeleteErrorException raised in volumes_client, the volume
   status is error_deleting, not ERROR.
So this is to pass full and accurate message to DeleteErrorException
to avoid the confusion.

Change-Id: I8cfd9f84b888b3380b6109e967b09f7fa74e4051
'}]
commit_message:
Pass more accurate error message to DeleteErrorException

Now we can get error messages like "Resource 595f6527-d84c-
4e14-a86f-c7be186a864c failed to delete and is in ERROR status",
and this has two problems:
1. It doesn't indicate which kind of resource, e.g., volume or server
2. For DeleteErrorException raised in volumes_client, the volume
   status is error_deleting, not ERROR.
So this is to pass full and accurate message to DeleteErrorException
to avoid the confusion.

Change-Id: I8cfd9f84b888b3380b6109e967b09f7fa74e4051

commit_message:
[FUP] Backport - krb-service-principal metadata per-Role

The rocky and queens backport of change[1] missed updating a
deprecated environment file that is no longer present since
stein.

This change updates the deprecated environment file to be a
j2 file with the jinja code to render the per-role metadata.

[1] I5ae3bc845b0a6ad6986d44b14ff4b0737a9b033b

Related-Bug: #1821377
Change-Id: Ie7c3c448e8d0f53a5347a19b6d0b99a0c6097114

commit_message:
Base profile for rsyslogd

Adds profile for rsyslogd composable service which aims to replace fluentd
with the same behaviour. This means that rsyslog will be tailing OpenStack
log files and forwarding it to central log collector (ELK)

Change-Id: I5e5aae692482ee1de6de298eb18c49563a2d7d29

commit_message:
Add ironic-python-agent to the default build project list

ironic-python-agent chnages have impact on OVB jobs.
AS such, we should run an OVB jobs as third party
on IPA changes.

This review ensures that we always build images with
IPA changes.

Change-Id: I46278decae1c00c2cf6d7034ccc6b05db0b2c9fc

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-07 19:20:20.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Fix some bogus `in (not_a_tuple)` uses

A couple of places in the libvirt driver had conditionals including:

 if something in (element):

which was clearly intended to be

 if something in (element,):

(I.e. `in $tuple`, not `in element` with redundant parens)

Fix 'em.

WIP: Clearly these aren't working as expected, so unit tests are either
missing or wrong. Fix those too.

Change-Id: I950d07eb533e0d43466c58e36b314aaaf8560251
"}, {'created': '2019-06-07 19:44:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix some bogus `in (not_a_tuple)` uses

A few places in the code had conditionals including:

 if something in (element):

which was clearly intended to be

 if something in (element,):

(I.e. `in $tuple`, not `in element` with redundant parens) or just

 if something == element:

Fix 'em.

NOTE: These weren't actually latent bugs because

 'foo' in ('foo')

which is the same as

 'foo' in 'foo'

returns True. In order to be a bug, the left operand would have to be
able to be a substring of the right:

 'foo' in ('foobar')  # True
 'foo' in ('foobar',) # False

...which I don't think is possible in any of the scenarios found.

NOTE: I considered writing a hacking rule for this, but it was going to
be tough to hit things like:

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py:374:    return "DELETE FROM %s WHERE %s in (SELECT T1.%s FROM (%s) as T1)" % (
nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/359_add_service_uuid.py:31:    if uuid_index_name not in (i['name'] for i in indexes):
nova/quota.py:461:                    val for val in (quotas.get(key), project_quotas.get(key))
nova/tests/functional/test_servers_provider_tree.py:326:        for uuid in (all_uuids - agg_uuids):
nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_hypervisors.py:124:        if not marker_found and marker in (str(hyper.id), hyper.uuid):
nova/tests/unit/test_hacking.py:894:        for filename in (good_filenames + bad_filenames):

Change-Id: I950d07eb533e0d43466c58e36b314aaaf8560251

 if something in (element):

which was clearly intended to be

 if something in (element,):

Fix those [1] and introduce hacking rule N363 to disallow this kind of
thing in the future.

[1] NOTE: These weren't actually latent bugs because

returns True. In order to be a bug, the left operand would have to be
able to be a substring of the right:

 'foo' in ('foobar')  # True
 'foo' in ('foobar',) # False

...which I don't think is possible in any of the scenarios found.

Change-Id: I950d07eb533e0d43466c58e36b314aaaf8560251

commit_message:
Hacking N363: `in (not_a_tuple)`

A few places in the code had conditionals including:

 if something in (element):

which was clearly intended to be

 if something in (element,):

(I.e. `in $tuple`, not `in element` with redundant parens) or just

 if something == element:

Fix those [1] and introduce hacking rule N363 to disallow this kind of
thing in the future.

[1] NOTE: These weren't actually latent bugs because

 'foo' in ('foo')

which is the same as

 'foo' in 'foo'

returns True. In order to be a bug, the left operand would have to be
able to be a substring of the right:

 'foo' in ('foobar')  # True
 'foo' in ('foobar',) # False

...which I don't think is possible in any of the scenarios found.

Change-Id: I950d07eb533e0d43466c58e36b314aaaf8560251

A previous patch [1] attempted to make sure that tests would never

threads are building (almost) real instances and such.

commit_message:
Mock time.sleep() in unit tests

A previous patch [1] attempted to make sure that tests would never
sleep() unless they really meant to. That turned out to be too invasive,
and too difficult to get right. But it revealed all of the places in the
nova codebase where real nonzero sleep()s were being done in test code.

Some of those are necessary: specifically the ones in functional test
code, which are doing things like _wait_for_server_status while other
threads are building (almost) real instances and such.

But almost all of the ones in unit tests are just wasting time. So this
commit mocks time.sleep() in those.

[1] If971c31380b1c5d1cc242846fb9c0779f03bbd19

Change-Id: I8ca348ab1a671b943c17dfec9ada2103aeb7cd84

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-06 18:02:25.000000000', 'message': "Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479
Related-Bug: #1817833
"}]
commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479

commit_message:
Fix invalid privsep.readpty test

It was noted that test_readpty was using misspelled assertion methods
asert_called_with and asert_has_calls.

Correcting these typos revealed that the test case was actually broken.

This commit fixes the spelling errors and also refactors the test to
make it work correctly.

Co-Authored-By: Eric Fried <openstack@fried.cc>

Change-Id: I9dadf768f9ce2b943c73238ba17e9aba0cf01b7a

commit_message:
Make RequestContext(instance_lock_checked) fail

The instance_lock_checked kwarg was added to RequestContext in [1], no
longer used in Nova since [2], and deprecated with a warning in [3].
This commit removes all handling of this kwarg, which will cause using
it to blow up with a TypeError in the super().__init__.

[1] I1127e31d86a061a93a64ee1eb4a4d900d8bf49b5
[2] Ic18017a16c5bffee85a43db65ff17283599a27ba
[3] Ib0b23a47c2e833073108af6700b16f8026631a83

Change-Id: Ie5f5a0ae018ce601c588a466399515159d8f58c0

[{'created': '2019-06-14 21:44:10.000000000', 'message': 'Implements karbor events notifications

Getting the messages from Karbor like:
  - Plan create/update/delete
  - Checkpoint create/update/available
  - Restore create
  - Scheduled Operations create/delete
  - Triggers create/update/delete

This should add and send the desired messages to RabbitMQ with the
start and end identifiers for each message
(e.g. karbor.plan_create.start, karbor.plan_create.end). The
notification code was done in a similar fashion than the
notifications from the Trove project.

Implements:  blueprint karbor-event-notifications
Closes-Bug: 1797462
Change-Id: Id850e1e50469659c034aa17ab994ad7e19478e5e
'}]
commit_message:
Implements karbor events notifications

Getting the messages from Karbor like:
  - Plan create/update/delete
  - Checkpoint create/update/available
  - Restore create
  - Scheduled Operations create/delete
  - Triggers create/update/delete

This should add and send the desired messages to RabbitMQ with the
start and end identifiers for each message
(e.g. karbor.plan_create.start, karbor.plan_create.end). The
notification code was done in a similar fashion than the
notifications from the Trove project.

Implements:  blueprint karbor-event-notifications
Closes-Bug: 1797462
Change-Id: Id850e1e50469659c034aa17ab994ad7e19478e5e

commit_message:
Align logging in the amphora

This patch configures the primary components of the amphora to log
to syslog using consistent logging facilities.
By default, user traffic logs will go to LOG_LOCAL0 and the amphora
processes (haproxy, keepalived, etc.) will log to LOG_LOCAL1.

This is a patch supporting log offloading.

Change-Id: Ifda91e0310e812e34f1e398dd3176af8a9c58f89
Story: 1665069
Task: 5486

Dropping support of 42.3

42.3 will not be maintained anymore, and it's better to focus on
Leap 15 instead.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-06 09:29:16.000000000', 'message': "Restore the original meaning of the code

In Python, when we use @property, the method will be
decorated by property.

When we call method self.strategy.datasource_backend()[1],
Actually it did two things:
1. call self.strategy.datasource_backend()
2. accord the method's return value[2], call self._datasource_backend()

[1]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/master/watcher/tests/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/test_base.py#L87
[2]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/master/watcher/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/base.py#L370

But in this part, we just want it to perform the first step.
So we have to use self.strategy.datasource_backend instead of
self.strategy.datasource_backend()

The reason why the unittest does not report an error is
because the returned value is a mock object, and the second step
is executed without error, for example:

python -m unittest  watcher.tests.decision_engine.strategy.strategies.test_base

(Pdb) x=self.strategy.datasource_backend
(Pdb) type(x)
<class 'mock.mock.MagicMock'>
(Pdb) x
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()' id='139740418102608'>
(Pdb) x()
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()()' id='139740410824976'>
(Pdb) self.strategy.datasource_backend()
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()()' id='139740410824976'>

Change-Id: I3305d9afe8ed79e1dc3affe02ba067ac06cece42
"}, {'created': '2019-06-06 09:33:46.000000000', 'message': "Restore the original meaning of the code

[2]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/master/watcher/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/base.py#L370

But in this part, we just want it to perform the first step.
So we have to use self.strategy.datasource_backend instead of

(Pdb) type(x)

"}, {'created': '2019-06-12 16:16:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix property access in test_global_preference* tests

In Python, when we use @property, the method will be
decorated by property.

When we call method self.strategy.datasource_backend()[1],
Actually it did two things:
1. call self.strategy.datasource_backend()
2. according to  the method's return value[2], call self._datasource_backend()

[1]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/bd8636f3f/watcher/tests/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/test_base.py#L87
[2]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/bd8636f3f/watcher/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/base.py#L368

But in this part, we just want it to perform the first step.
So we have to use self.strategy.datasource_backend instead of
self.strategy.datasource_backend()

The reason why the unittest does not report an error is
because the returned value is a mock object, and the second step
is executed without error, for example:

python -m unittest  watcher.tests.decision_engine.strategy.strategies.test_base
(Pdb) x=self.strategy.datasource_backend
(Pdb) type(x)

commit_message:
Fix property access in test_global_preference* tests

In Python, when we use @property, the method will be
decorated by property.

When we call method self.strategy.datasource_backend()[1],
Actually it did two things:
1. call self.strategy.datasource_backend()
2. according to  the method's return value[2], call self._datasource_backend()

[1]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/bd8636f3f/watcher/tests/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/test_base.py#L87
[2]. https://github.com/openstack/watcher/blob/bd8636f3f/watcher/decision_engine/strategy/strategies/base.py#L368

But in this part, we just want it to perform the first step.
So we have to use self.strategy.datasource_backend instead of
self.strategy.datasource_backend()

The reason why the unittest does not report an error is
because the returned value is a mock object, and the second step
is executed without error, for example:

python -m unittest  watcher.tests.decision_engine.strategy.strategies.test_base
(Pdb) x=self.strategy.datasource_backend
(Pdb) type(x)
<class 'mock.mock.MagicMock'>
(Pdb) x
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()' id='139740418102608'>
(Pdb) x()
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()()' id='139740410824976'>
(Pdb) self.strategy.datasource_backend()
<MagicMock name='DataSourceManager().get_backend()()' id='139740410824976'>

To make the tests more robust, the underlying backend function
is mocked to be not callable.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I3305d9afe8ed79e1dc3affe02ba067ac06cece42

commit_message:
Don't render None as "null"

In a config file you never want the string "null" in place of a null
value. Just render an empty string instead.

Change-Id: Ibe145c4929d4944cd8d51c07a64aee6fd5f831f2
Closes-Bug: #1830967
Story: 2005797
(cherry picked from commit 75d527ab8fd13185f8db05ad69c43b3c89e06dc3)

commit_message:
Don't render None as "null"

In a config file you never want the string "null" in place of a null
value. Just render an empty string instead.

Change-Id: Ibe145c4929d4944cd8d51c07a64aee6fd5f831f2
Closes-Bug: #1830967
Story: 2005797

(cherry picked from commit 75d527ab8fd13185f8db05ad69c43b3c89e06dc3)

commit_message:
Set cache_backend for token caching

'fernet' is the token provider since octata. As we've memcached
in the undercloud, we should enable caching by setting
cache_backend to 'dogpile.cache.memcached'.

Change-Id: I4b040d25b2cb83f40cbd8e8caf6890feba586b60
Closes-Bug: #1832437
(cherry picked from commit e2a4d90aad3a6978ea9a6e4de132adca51df0c15)

commit_message:
Set cache_backend for token caching

'fernet' is the token provider since octata. As we've memcached
in the undercloud, we should enable caching by setting
cache_backend to 'dogpile.cache.memcached'.

Change-Id: I4b040d25b2cb83f40cbd8e8caf6890feba586b60
Closes-Bug: #1832437
(cherry picked from commit e2a4d90aad3a6978ea9a6e4de132adca51df0c15)

subject: Move undercloud upgrade pre-requisites into tasks.
messages: [{'account_id': 21537, 'date': '2019-06-12 06:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-06-12 10:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29222, 'date': '2019-06-12 12:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2019-06-14 14:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-12 06:04:27.000000000', 'message': "Move undercloud upgrade pre-requisites into tasks.

Up to now we were keeping the packages updates needed before running the
undercloud upgrade inside the template templates/undercloud_upgrade.sh.j2.
However, as we need to include new pre-requisites, plus the fact that for
the downstream yum is not present (it's dnf instead) and upstream we still
have yum it's better to ensure these pre-requisites leveraging the benefits
the Ansible tasks bring.

The new set of tasks that will take care of updating those packages and
ensuring the needed services are enabled will be in
common/undercloud_prerequisites.yaml as we'll need them for both the
undercloud upgrade and update.

Also, this patch removes the py_ver variable and relies on use_oooq variable
to differentiate between the python version we need for the packages.

Change-Id: I40b17910ecd963d50a2074081d6dea285d8c9dcc
(cherry picked from commit 999e1803a70383796e6b8465c9405d0b6506d716)
"}]
commit_message:
Move undercloud upgrade pre-requisites into tasks.

Up to now we were keeping the packages updates needed before running the
undercloud upgrade inside the template templates/undercloud_upgrade.sh.j2.
However, as we need to include new pre-requisites, plus the fact that for
the downstream yum is not present (it's dnf instead) and upstream we still
have yum it's better to ensure these pre-requisites leveraging the benefits
the Ansible tasks bring.

The new set of tasks that will take care of updating those packages and
ensuring the needed services are enabled will be in
common/undercloud_prerequisites.yaml as we'll need them for both the
undercloud upgrade and update.

Also, this patch removes the py_ver variable and relies on use_oooq variable
to differentiate between the python version we need for the packages.

Change-Id: I40b17910ecd963d50a2074081d6dea285d8c9dcc
(cherry picked from commit 999e1803a70383796e6b8465c9405d0b6506d716)

[{'created': '2019-06-14 09:37:50.000000000', 'message': 'Explicitly set ansible_python_interpreter in external upgrade playbook

During the run of external upgrade playbook, we connect to systems
with different OS releases via delegate_to, which seems to confuse the
autodetection of Python interpreter. Set it explicitly to
platform-python which should work both on EL7 and EL8.

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieb486f0c3e4de7229cdd2be49d4d0f038668f06d
Closes-Bug: #1830713
(cherry picked from commit 770b578bfbb151a91184f1e6f403e952def0c30e)
'}]
commit_message:
Explicitly set ansible_python_interpreter in external upgrade playbook

During the run of external upgrade playbook, we connect to systems
with different OS releases via delegate_to, which seems to confuse the
autodetection of Python interpreter. Set it explicitly to
platform-python which should work both on EL7 and EL8.

Co-Authored-By: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ieb486f0c3e4de7229cdd2be49d4d0f038668f06d
Closes-Bug: #1830713
(cherry picked from commit 770b578bfbb151a91184f1e6f403e952def0c30e)

commit_message:
Handle openvswitch meta-package on undercloud upgrade.

As done for the overcloud in [0], we need to include the
same special package handling in the tasks in charge of
upgrading the undercloud.

This patch adds special handling for the rhosp-openvswitch
layered product package to ensure that openvswitch networking
remains available during the upgrade.

[0] - https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/1773afb0689c8fded9bce2dff4c1f8d9406c8294

(cherry picked from commit bbc18dd8d8db9f24bfb1e7dbb5ee760bd9036465)

Closes-Bug: #1830627

commit_message:
[FUP] Update sriov_pf.yaml samle with ethtool_opt

This change updates sriov_pf.yaml sample file with a
usage example of ethtool_opt attribute that was added
to sriov_pf port type.

Change-Id: Ib12901d5fad51ac40d2a9d8cdc13919b7d64c92e
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663458/
(cherry picked from commit 7668abb300d6c607814bfca209135781cc920ecc)

commit_message:
Add support for ethtool options for sriov_pf ports

There are deployment cases where ethtool configurations
are required to be performed on a sriov_pf port.

Main Changes:
- Add ethtool options to sriov_pf port type.
- Add ethtool_opts to sriov_pf schema

Change-Id: Idbc07312820bda5a113d5a9204052c76f9993e80
(cherry picked from commit 2c13c0eac0f02aec639837d7ed3329bedfd28660)

I was not able to test the full patch.
Only tested that this patch discards fluentd container to do the copy of the logs.

To test it I just run this two commands:
Fluentd container:
if ! echo "/var/log/containers                                                                                                         
/var/log/containers/fluentd                                                                                                             
/var/log" | grep -x '/var/log[/]*' | grep -x '/var/log[/]*' 2>1 > /dev/null ; then  echo 'ok'; else echo 'false'; fi

if ! echo "/var/log/containers/nova

/etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
/etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
/etc/puppet
/var/lib/kolla/config_files/nova_conductor.json
/dev/log
/etc/localtime
/etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
/etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/nova
/etc/hosts
/etc/ssh/ssh_known_hosts " | grep -x '/var/log[/]*' | grep -x '/var/log[/]*' 2>1 > /dev/null ; then  echo 'ok'; else echo 'false'; fi

The result was ok'}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-06-14 09:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Handle recursive copy of /var/log from containers

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/578892/ handled
the recursive copy but assumed /var/log is mounted
to /var/log inside the container, The destination
mount can differ like in fluentd_client [1]. To handle
such cases use <container cli> inspect to detect if
/var/log is mounted inside container or not.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/pike/docker/services/fluentd-client.yaml#L116

Change-Id: I349399b569774b92724978f9c6003b88393cf84d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-04 18:55:34.000000000', 'message': 'Filter unprintable ASCII during enumeration

When enumerating DCIM_ControllerView, the DriverVersion field may have
unprintable ASCII characters in it if the server has a BOSS card. In
the past, it was observed that this field could contain unprintable
non-ASCII characters, but unprintable ASCII characters have been
found in it as well.

This fix changes the filtering so that only printable ASCII
characters and the tab character pass the filter.

Closes-Bug: 1816194
Change-Id: If7274fed19fb763aa7c2e4adc3676a4e3c26aee0

commit_message:
Filter unprintable ASCII during enumeration

When enumerating DCIM_ControllerView, the DriverVersion field may have
unprintable ASCII characters in it if the server has a BOSS card. In
the past, it was observed that this field could contain unprintable
non-ASCII characters, but unprintable ASCII characters have been
found in it as well.

This fix changes the filtering so that only printable ASCII
characters and the tab character pass the filter.

Closes-Bug: 1816194
Change-Id: If7274fed19fb763aa7c2e4adc3676a4e3c26aee0
(cherry picked from commit 95440920fd487cea921883f71f619fdfa8229669)

commit_message:
[FUP] Update sriov_pf.yaml samle with ethtool_opt

This change updates sriov_pf.yaml sample file with a
usage example of ethtool_opt attribute that was added
to sriov_pf port type.

Change-Id: Ib12901d5fad51ac40d2a9d8cdc13919b7d64c92e
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664780
(cherry picked from commit 7668abb300d6c607814bfca209135781cc920ecc)

commit_message:
Add support for ethtool options for sriov_pf ports

There are deployment cases where ethtool configurations
are required to be performed on a sriov_pf port.

Main Changes:
- Add ethtool options to sriov_pf port type.
- Add ethtool_opts to sriov_pf schema

Change-Id: Idbc07312820bda5a113d5a9204052c76f9993e80
(cherry picked from commit 2c13c0eac0f02aec639837d7ed3329bedfd28660)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-04 18:55:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix iDRAC reset

The current code waits for 3 consecutive failed pings, each 10 seconds
apart to determine that an iDRAC has gone down during an iDRAC reset.
This is too long for some servers, as the iDRAC may come back up before
the 3rd ping failure.  This results in a failure to detect the iDRAC
going down, which causes a timeout on the reset.

This patch changes the code to wait for only 2 consecutive ping
failures, which is what our highly tested downstream code does.

Closes-Bug: 1816195
Change-Id: Iac21d5eb722834089cbe4a2e7e19370a951951f0
(cherry picked from commit e204c367ab118878aa5202e10d74c3c28de8ba21)

commit_message:
Fix iDRAC reset

The current code waits for 3 consecutive failed pings, each 10 seconds
apart to determine that an iDRAC has gone down during an iDRAC reset.
This is too long for some servers, as the iDRAC may come back up before
the 3rd ping failure.  This results in a failure to detect the iDRAC
going down, which causes a timeout on the reset.

This patch changes the code to wait for only 2 consecutive ping
failures, which is what our highly tested downstream code does.

Closes-Bug: 1816195
Change-Id: Iac21d5eb722834089cbe4a2e7e19370a951951f0
(cherry picked from commit e204c367ab118878aa5202e10d74c3c28de8ba21)

commit_message:
Add rarp protocol for neutron constants

We should support rarp protocol(0x8035) for live-migration
A release note is also included.

Partial-Bug: #1831404

commit_message:
Add unit tests for validator

We need to bump our minimum version for mock to 3.0.0 in order for
mocking of 'open' to work correctly with the ConfigParser. From the
mock changelog: "Issue #32933: unittest.mock.mock_open() now supports
iteration over the file contents."

Change-Id: I9522083b7b0f785fe0e9cbdf8a9042112820bed4

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-25 10:24:34.000000000', 'message': 'Don't use logger before it is configured

This patch removes the first call to check_provider. Because logging
is not configured when the file is imported, any calls to logger.error
result only this unhelpful error message being shown:

  No handlers could be found for logger "stacktrain.config.general"

The check_provider call in st.py is the only one we need.

backport: rocky queens

Closes-Bug: #1803341

Change-Id: Ie75ca928b13a51433f8d61500407049a0e636d45
'}]
commit_message:
Don't use logger before it is configured

This patch removes the first call to check_provider. Because logging
is not configured when the file is imported, any calls to logger.error
result only this unhelpful error message being shown:

  No handlers could be found for logger "stacktrain.config.general"

The check_provider call in st.py is the only one we need.

backport: rocky queens

Closes-Bug: #1803341

Change-Id: Ie75ca928b13a51433f8d61500407049a0e636d45

commit_message:
Simplify locking code

NodeInfo accepts a lock instance when instantiated, it is only used
in the node clean up periodic task, such implementation introduces
complexity on the lock abstraction. This patch moves node locking
out of get_node.

_get_lock_ctx is removed for it only duplicates _get_lock according to
current usage.

Change-Id: I4e946942ce684b27062d1a42c68faf1d92569489

commit_message:

This is temporary patch to resolve cross-dependecies caused by
tempest_install_method, which is not defined for third party

Without this patch, the fast8 tox environment runs flake8 differently

'}]
commit_message:
Add flake8 ignore list to fast8 script

Without this patch, the fast8 tox environment runs flake8 differently
than the pep8 environment does, excluding the ignore list. This patch
ensures they have the same ignore list so that results are consistent.

Change-Id: I3f573e9627b17896fdd57261b9de692d49857140

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Remove auth_uri""

Merge this revert when [1] is merged and propagated to packages since Mistral will support www_authenticate_uri then. [1]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/594187

This reverts commit 5a932874744399ce3330b98bb986ba02803d9394.

Change-Id: I2ff34f358dbc056a59f310d203883844f4db54e5

[{'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-05-23 08:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-23 15:37:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a change to the master branch this was picked from?  Or is there no work on master due to the deprecation?'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-05-26 05:52:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This code does not exist on master branch any more due to the deprecation'}, {'account_id': 13438, 'date': '2019-05-26 09:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30381, 'date': '2019-05-26 22:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-28 13:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-04 08:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can we go forward with this patch?'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-04 09:38:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure we can even approve patches for stable branches. I'm in favor of it but there were some doubts about it. Assuming we can move forward with this patch, does it require a release note and/or story?  It would only make sense to require it if we would cut a stable release. I'm also in favor of it for maintained releases https://releases.openstack.org/#release-series"}, {'account_id': 13438, 'date': '2019-06-04 09:44:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Does deprecating nlbaas in train mean that it's not supported for earlier branches too? I doubt that."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-04 09:49:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, that is what I'm not certain and personally I'd like to see neutron-lbaas supported for releases still in maintenance mode (supported down to Queens until 2019-08-25 as per https://releases.openstack.org/#release-series)"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-06-04 18:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is fine as Stein is still in "maintained" per https://releases.openstack.org/#release-series.
However, it must have an associated story and release note describing the bug this is fixing.'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-05 05:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13438, 'date': '2019-06-05 07:44:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-05 10:27:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-06 06:33:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-06 06:53:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not really sure why the releasenotes job fails. Can someone help?"}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-06 12:10:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm not sure either. I can build locally just fine. The command seems to be the same Zuul runs, too: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/build-releasenotes/tasks/main.yaml#L127-L129"}, {'account_id': 20363, 'date': '2019-06-10 04:16:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-06-12 18:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-06-12 18:35:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

I removed the releasenotes related changes herein.

As per [1] the releasenotes job will not work for projects that don't have a master branch. Until then we can either proceed without releasenotes in patches, and/or disable the job [1]. For more details see the commit message in [1].



[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664874/"}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-06-12 21:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I agree with Michael in IRC, we should disable the job and continue including releasenotes in the patches.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-06-12 22:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Support URL query params in healthmonitor url_path

Update the regex used for the url_path validation to also allow '?'
as RFC1738 allows it.
This will allow urls like '/a?x=y' to be accepted.

Story: 2005824
Change-Id: I2986601481aeb276ea7c5e1ad324a6577386a2b1

commit_message:
Add Vault Secret Store Plugin

Barbican can utilize Hashicorp Vault software
as a secret store backend. Added a new plugin
manifest to configure the vault_plugin section.

Change-Id: Idef1bdfd20b4820963e084657b46e07660be248c
(cherry picked from commit 7ab351d8d5cbc4c83bfd2ac2c93b960ce5f2e2c4)

commit_message:
OVS Revalidator and handler threads config

OVS revalidator hanlder threads are not contained to limited cores.
This patch will enable them to be configured in puppet vswitch module

Change-Id: I576b00bb28d0d531eb91a856632a7b5afe552f43
Closes-Bug: #1822571
(cherry picked from commit 6bc5b206e72409baf6dc9883d0e4789a7155bbb0)

commit_message:
Fixes creating nondefault type volumes from volume

Horizon ignores volume type of source volume and tries to set default
type to newly created volume. Proposed patch makes Horizon inherit
volume type from the source

Closes-bug: #1830759
Closes-bug: #1599225
Change-Id: Ice18259a59d1b7e347ffab89ca931985d49e6895

commit_message:
Remove glance-cache-manage from documentation

This patch removes obsolete glance-cache-manage command
from documentation.

Change-Id: Ibecb187a7251bbb91094251327592332d9450375
Closes-Bug: #1795786
(cherry picked from commit d8cbe3fc52be09b5e35033b7e0a5c45d4a0ce343)

subject: Rename async package to async_

[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-09-27 13:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-09-27 14:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

This is kind of a major change to backport to a stable branch.

The officially support Python 3 version in Rocky was 3.5, so I do not think this should be backported to stable/rocky.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-09-27 15:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I see your point, however support of only Py3.5 is really painful for downstream distros that are trying to support up to Py3.7 for rocky.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-14 15:57:58.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Not needed with the officially supported runtimes for rocky and doesn't meet our stable requirements."}]

In Python 3.7, "async" is a keyword. To prevent it from
conflicting, rename the async package to async_.

Change-Id: I1eaf87eedb86679d9ca9323aac05f0770c33efea
Closes-Bug: #1781617
(cherry picked from commit c58e5e02af76cad3967d22d14c63794c6d60456f)

commit_message:
Rename async package to async_

In Python 3.7, "async" is a keyword. To prevent it from
conflicting, rename the async package to async_.

Change-Id: I1eaf87eedb86679d9ca9323aac05f0770c33efea
Closes-Bug: #1781617
(cherry picked from commit c58e5e02af76cad3967d22d14c63794c6d60456f)

I agree with Kaitlin. What's the harm with Castellan being part of requirements?"}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-26 16:22:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

tests need to be fixed.

But in general this is a good change. To answer Kaitlin and Joel, yes, there is precendent for this. See glance_store, keystone, etc. Things that are optional are not supposed to be listed in requirements.txt. Doing so imposes an unnecessary burden on products to vet, build, get legal clearances, etc. things that they will not actually use. It also imposes an unnecessary burden on operators to find, vet, maintain, etc. something they will not actually use. This is what extras are for, to indicate optional requirements and then products, operators, etc. can make the decision of whether they want to install/use something or not.'}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2016-02-26 16:52:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What about other modules like cryptography? Shouldn't they also be moved in this case?"}, {'account_id': 7764, 'date': '2016-02-26 20:40:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I agree with Joel and Kaitlin on this. I don't see the need to remove Castellan from requirements, especially if image signing is going to be supported going forward."}, {'account_id': 13393, 'date': '2016-02-26 21:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13393, 'date': '2016-02-26 21:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-26 22:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Kaitlin, Joel, Peter... The code with the castellan dependency is going away (See https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/09a0acefc7d27b85e7145611a3852bcf0765f769). It doesn't make sense to have a hard requirement for something that is only used in code that folks aren't supposed to use anymore.

It's a good point that cryptography should also be made optional with the same reasoning."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-26 23:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-26 23:21:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-26 23:24:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@Nikhil I will pick this up, Ken confirmed he is happy with that.'}, {'account_id': 17116, 'date': '2016-07-26 14:28:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2016-07-26 16:44:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Dependencies of image signature verification should not be hard
> requirements since glance does not require signature verification.

I'm curious about the big picture here.

What are the criteria for including something in 'requirements.txt'?

In this particular case, image signature is a native feature of Glance.

It seems funny (to me anyway) that the mechanism for operators to enable this feature would change from:

 1) install glance (and its requirements) -- so far so good
 2) start glance -- seems to work
 3) try to use the signature feature -- it works

 to

 1) install glance (and its requirements) -- so far so good
 2) start glance -- seems to work
 3) try to use the signature feature -- it fails
 4) go through the logs to figure out what happened
 5) install the extra requirements, go to (3)

OpenStack has a reputation for being tricky to install/manage; for me this change makes things a little more complicated for operators than they were before."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-07-26 18:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

> > Dependencies of image signature verification should not be hard
 > > requirements since glance does not require signature
 > verification.
 > 
 > I'm curious about the big picture here.
 > 
 > What are the criteria for including something in 'requirements.txt'?
 > 
 > In this particular case, image signature is a native feature of
 > Glance.
 > 
 > It seems funny (to me anyway) that the mechanism for operators to
 > enable this feature would change from:
 > 
 > 1) install glance (and its requirements) -- so far so good
 > 2) start glance -- seems to work
 > 3) try to use the signature feature -- it works
 > 
 > to
 > 
 > 1) install glance (and its requirements) -- so far so good
 > 2) start glance -- seems to work
 > 3) try to use the signature feature -- it fails
 > 4) go through the logs to figure out what happened
 > 5) install the extra requirements, go to (3)
 > 
 > OpenStack has a reputation for being tricky to install/manage; for
 > me this change makes things a little more complicated for operators
 > than they were before.

This is a good question. And my answer is little more objective for such a nice subjective question but that's the best I can give for newton-3.

There are many situations where the underlying tools to successfully run a command may fail:

* if using tasks, you don't have qemu-img installed.
* if running nova, you don't have glance installed or if glance is not installed in a way nova can communicate properly (which will be realized to fail at the boot process/smoke tests)

In some cases like requirement of running glance-api is understood to be even non-documented as glance is core project whereas requirement of qemu-img is a advanced requirement and may even have assumptions on the type of operating system you are running glance/nova on.

I think , what's more important is the expectation of barbican to be running (like nova expects glance) so, the dependency on client is secondary. We should note that anyone using this advanced feature (while it may be first class citizen in glance), they have to go through a bit of pain like having the right properties on image, making sure they use appropriate algorithms, etc. So, if we can keep the dependencies needed in documented at the same place as the rest of the docs are, we should be giving a fair playground to the ops to use this feature.

This type of implementation is similar to what we are doing for glance_store, except for the fact that the type of store is defined early. 


Food for thought is: would have a paste ini entry for signature utils be a better route?"}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-07-26 18:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

-1 for the inline error'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-26 19:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified-1

@Nikhil

> if using tasks, you don't have qemu-img installed.

There is no mechanism to express that the qemu-img binary is a requirement. If it were a pure python package it would be in requirements.txt.

> if running nova, you don't have glance installed or if glance is not installed in a way nova can communicate properly

There is no mechanism to say that 'a verified working glance' installation is required. There is a mechanism to say you require the glance client -- and that is expressed in nova's requirements.txt."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-07-28 16:29:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> @Nikhil
 > 
 > > if using tasks, you don't have qemu-img installed.
 > 
 > There is no mechanism to express that the qemu-img binary is a
 > requirement. If it were a pure python package it would be in
 > requirements.txt.
 > 
 > > if running nova, you don't have glance installed or if glance is
 > not installed in a way nova can communicate properly
 > 
 > There is no mechanism to say that 'a verified working glance'
 > installation is required. There is a mechanism to say you require
 > the glance client -- and that is expressed in nova's
 > requirements.txt.

@Stuart: exactly my point. it's play it by ear when convenient.

All of these are left to judicious analysis when there's no option. Last time I checked barbican doesn't come running with default devstack, neither do any signed images. Ops need documentation to get image signing running and it doesn't hurt to add these as optional dependencies when it makes lives of packagers easier. I am a bit against the argument that we'd do it because it's done this way in other places, like a pure python requirement."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-28 20:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified-1

I've tried to dig a bit into why the futures+futurist+py34 issue happens but to no result yet. Also, lack of b/w is making me quit before I get too determined to find the outcome.


Basically, the info so far is:

A latest release of futures isn't py3 compatible. See more details here:

  * https://github.com/datastax/python-driver/pull/387

This is rather surprising though, as it seems to fail for this patch with versions futures==3.0.5 & futurist==0.18.0

whereas for the following patch the same versions work

  * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/361393/
  * http://logs.openstack.org/93/361393/2/check/gate-glance-python34-db/58234b6/tox/py34-3.log.txt


From the looks of it, a transient dependency could potentially be issue but which one will need some more time spending...


Besides, this commit will need release notes and some reviews after tests work. I am of opinion this won't make it into Newton."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 04:54:35.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-14 15:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

No longer needed.'}]

marked for removal should never have been hard requirements since
glance does not require signature verification. But they should certainly
not be hard requirements now, with that code marked for removal and
not supposed to be used. This therefore shifts castellan and
cryptography from requirements.txt to setup.cfg extras.

commit_message:
Make signature dependencies optional

Dependencies of image signature verification should not be hard
requirements since glance does not require signature verification. This
therefore shifts castellan and cryptography from requirements.txt to
setup.cfg extras.

Co-Authored-By: Niall Bunting <niall.bunting@hpe.com>
Change-Id: I0a757c210326d5d1397a9ca1c6fe67243d03f4b9
Closes-Bug: #1549428

commit_message:
Add Python 3.5 venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim support for
Python 3.5. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

Change-Id: I102ebfd39ec5344704d9b071a767df3120c4515f

commit_message:
Integrate oslo.config validator

Adds the oslo configuration file validator as a new entry point.

The config validator is a tool intended for use by operators to validate
their modified configuration files before standing up services in production.

Change-Id: Ia9c61a4c272f99ccf9cf439efa887272e22514c8
Depends-On: I78d3621afda226f5968963ef408507234dfead4c

[{'created': '2016-05-20 14:10:55.000000000', 'message': 'Let setup.py compile_catalog process all language files

Two years ago the translation files have been split into several
files, separating the log messages of different log levels from each
other, like X.pot, X-log-warning.pot, X-log-info.pot, and so on.
However, the setup.py command `compile_catalogs`, that comes from the
babel package and compiles the corresponding .po files into .mo
files, only supported one file per python package.  This means that
during packaging `compile_catalogs` never compiled the X-log-*.po
files, so the corresponding translations were always missing.

Since babel 2.3 the domain can be set to a space separated list of
domains.  This change adds the the additional log level files to the
domain list and adds a requirement for babel>=2.3.4.

commit_message:
Let setup.py compile_catalog process all language files

Two years ago the translation files have been split into several
files, separating the log messages of different log levels from each
other, like X.pot, X-log-warning.pot, X-log-info.pot, and so on.
However, the setup.py command `compile_catalogs`, that comes from the
babel package and compiles the corresponding .po files into .mo
files, only supported one file per python package.  This means that
during packaging `compile_catalogs` never compiled the X-log-*.po
files, so the corresponding translations were always missing.

Since babel 2.3 the domain can be set to a space separated list of
domains.  This change adds the the additional log level files to the
domain list.

The obsolete check that .po and .pot files are valid is removed from
tox.ini.

Change-Id: I35f0f3d82e5939f91c05ac62bc7f0e5edcdcd2d6
Closes-Bug: #1536226

I don't think we should say we support python 3 until all glance tests pass under py35.  We're still skipping two functional tests.  Here's were we're tracking progress:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/glance-pike-python35-goal

This isn't a priority right now for Pike RC-1 next week.  I'm not averse to getting it in if someone is able to fix the tests; otherwise, we'll be doing this in Queens."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-14 15:53:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Create a tuned role

This change imports the tuned content from the tripleo-heat-templates
project and creates a role which can be used throughout the tripleo
project ecosystem.

The role will test in docker containers running both fedora28 and
centos7.

Change-Id: I90b5b63959c754989416544f83089f1ca4b53be2
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
package rootwrap filters for ironic-lib

It seems ironic services (which are using ironic-lib)
require these rootwrap filters to be available. It isn't
100% clear to me whether they need to be under ironic/rootwrap.d
or whether we can patch the rootwrap config to include ironic-lib..

Change-Id: Iaa8dba6254492cedd1d3d7c1f4b5c6d505c189e4

commit_message:
[FUP] Update sriov_pf.yaml samle with ethtool_opt

This change updates sriov_pf.yaml sample file with a
usage example of ethtool_opt attribute that was added
to sriov_pf port type.

Change-Id: Ib12901d5fad51ac40d2a9d8cdc13919b7d64c92e
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663268/
(cherry picked from commit 7668abb300d6c607814bfca209135781cc920ecc)

commit_message:
Add support for ethtool options for sriov_pf ports

There are deployment cases where ethtool configurations
are required to be performed on a sriov_pf port.

Main Changes:
- Add ethtool options to sriov_pf port type.
- Add ethtool_opts to sriov_pf schema

Change-Id: Idbc07312820bda5a113d5a9204052c76f9993e80
(cherry picked from commit 2c13c0eac0f02aec639837d7ed3329bedfd28660)
